node.text:
The current generation of American kids may be one of the first generations to be less healthy and have shorter lifespans than their parents. 

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/3d3QCI3

node.text:
Body weight and satiety signals. I dive into one of the most fascinating series of studies I’ve ever come across.

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/3u38oBN

node.text:
Why do some pine nuts cause a bad taste in your mouth that can last for weeks?

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/3u25Cg5

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/3j2Is6p

The current generation of American kids may be one of the first generations to be less healthy and have shorter lifespans than their parents. 

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/3d3QCI3

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by NutritionFacts.org on July 23, 2021. May be an image of flower and text that says '"A regular, reliable source of vitamin B12 is critical for anyone eating a plant-based diet." -Dr. Michael Greger in How Not to Die N NutritionFacts.org'.

node.text:
Vitamin B12 is not made by plants or animals, but by microbes that blanket the earth.

To learn more about B12 on NutritionFacts.org, click the link in our bio and then select this photo. 

#DailyDozen #DailyDozenChallenge #HowNotToDie #HowNotToDiet #PlantBasedEating #PlantBased #NutritionFactsOrg #PlantPoweredDiet #PoweredByPlants #EatMorePlants #PlantBasedLifestyle #PlantBasedLiving #EatPlants #BeansAndGreens #WhereDoYouGetYourProtein #VeganHealth #VegetarianHealth #VeganNutrition #PlantBasedDiet #PlantBasedFood #WFPB #WholeFoodPlantBased #PlantStrong #B12Supplement #PlantBasedNutrition

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by NutritionFacts.org on July 23, 2021. May be an image of flower and text that says '"A regular, reliable source of vitamin B12 is critical for anyone eating a plant-based diet." -Dr. Michael Greger in How Not to Die N NutritionFacts.org'.

Photo by NutritionFacts.org on July 23, 2021. May be an image of flower and text that says 'Vitamin B12 is not made by plants or animals, but by microbes that blanket the earth. In today's sanitized, modern world, the water supply is commonly chlorinated to kill off any bacteria. So, while we don't get much B12 in the water anymore, we don't get much cholera either, which is a good thing! MNutritionFacts.org NutritionFacts.org'.

Photo by NutritionFacts.org on July 23, 2021. May be an image of flower and text that says 'A regular, reliable source of vitamin B12 is critical for anyone eating a plant-based diet. Though deficiency for those starting out with adequate stores may take years to develop, the results of B12 deficiency can be devastating, with cases reported of paralysis, psychosis, blindness and even death. /NutritionFacts.org NutritionFacts.org'.

Photo by NutritionFacts.org on July 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Dr. Greger has updated his recommendation for B12 supplementation, now suggesting at least 2,000 mcg (μg) cyanocobalamin once each week, ideally as a chewable, sublingual, or liquid supplement taken on an empty stomach, or at least 50 mcg daily of supplemental cyanocobalamin. (You needn't worry about taking too much.) /NutritionFacts.org NutritionFacts.org'.

Photo by NutritionFacts.org on July 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'You can also do servings of B12-fortified foods three times a day (at each meal), each containing at least 190 percent of the Daily Value listed on the nutrition facts label. (Based on the new labeling mandated to start January 1, 2020, the target is 4.5 mcg three times a day.) Note that those over age 65 essentially have only one option: taking 1,000 mcg a day. MNutritionFacts.org NutritionFacts.org'.
Photo by NutritionFacts.org on July 23, 2021. May be an image of text.
Photo by NutritionFacts.org on July 22, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
Beans, Berries, fruit, Veggies, Greens, Cruciferous, Flaxseed, Nuts and Seeds, Herbs and Spice, Whole Grains, Beverages, and Exercise. ⁠
⁠
Eat, Move, Track, Repeat. ⁠
⁠
It’s your regular routine that determines your long-term health. The Daily Dozen checklist is a simple health tracker that can help you to build healthy habits that includes some of the healthiest of healthy foods and exercise into your daily routine. Download the free Daily Dozen app today to get started! Learn more here: https://nutritionfacts.org/daily-dozen/⁠
*Click the link in our bio and then select this image to access the URL.⁠

node.text:
One of the ingredients of curry powder is turmeric. Besides being so good for you, turmeric gives the blend its beautiful yellow color. This curried chickpea is great in lettuce wraps, served as a dip, or on top of roasted sweet potatoes. The recipe is from The How Not to Die Cookbook

INGREDIENTS:
1½ cups cooked or 1 15.5-ounce BPA-free can or Tetra Pak salt-free chickpeas, drained and rinsed
1 1/2 teaspoons curry powder, or to taste
1 teaspoon lemon juice
1 teaspoon date sugar (optional)
1/4 teaspoon white miso paste
Savory Spice Blend* to taste
1/2 cup chopped celery
1/3 cup shredded carrot
1/3 cup chopped cashews
1/3 cup raisins
1 firm sweet apple, cored and chopped
1 tablespoon chopped scallion
2 cups dark leafy greens of choice or shredded lettuce

METHOD:
1. In a food processor, combine 1 cup of the chickpeas with the curry powder, lemon, date sugar, miso, and Savory Spice Blend to taste with 3 to 4 tablespoons of water. Process until smooth. Add the remaining ½ cup of chickpeas and the celery, carrot, cashews, raisins, apple, and scallion, and pulse just to combine and break up the chickpeas a bit. Taste and adjust the seasonings, if needed.

2. Serve on top of sweet potatoes, in lettuce wraps, or with 100% whole grain tortillas. 

Note: To prepare the sweet potatoes as seen in the video, wash the sweet potatoes well. Slice the sweet potatoes into thin slices and place onto a lined baking sheet. Roast on 425F until the sweet potatoes are well cooked (about 30-40 min).

node.text:
Here's a delicious breakfast or snack idea using just oats, bananas, and any add-ins of your choice. Serve these banana oat cookies for breakfast with some fresh fruit or enjoy on their own as a mid-day snack!

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup of rolled oats
2 medium-large ripe, spotty bananas

OPTIONAL ADD-INS:
up to 1/4 cup of frozen blueberries (raisins, nuts, seeds, or other dried, fresh or frozen fruit)
1/2-1 teaspoon cinnamon ( pumpkin pie spice or other favorite spices)

METHOD:
1. Preheat oven to 350F.
2. Mash bananas with a fork in a medium-sized bowl, until a pureed consistency is achieved.
3. In a food processor or blender, pulse the oats for 10 seconds to break into smaller fragments or blend into oat flour. This helps the cookies hold together. In a pinch, this recipe will also work with whole rolled oats. All options work, but will give the cookies a different texture.
4. Stir the oats, mashed bananas, and any add-ins to form a batter.
6. Line a cookie sheet with parchment paper or a silicone mat, scoop out desired amount of cookie dough and press down gently to flatten into cookies.
7. Bake for 15 minutes or until golden brown.
Makes about 4- 8 cookies.

Recipe from Mary, our Media Director.

node.text:
These oatmeal cookie dough bites are a perfect bite sized treat for your sweet tooth! Simple to make and only require a few ingredients. Recipe from Kristina (@kristinademuth), our Director of Nutrition and Social Media Strategy

INGREDIENTS
1 cup rolled oats
1/2 cup raw cashews or hemp seeds
1 teaspoon cinnamon
1/2 cup (packed full) pitted dates
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1-5 teaspoons of water, as needed
1/4 cup raisins 

METHOD:
1. In a food processor, add the oats, cashews (or hemp seeds), and cinnamon. Process until oats and cashews are a coarse flour.

2. Add the dates to the food processor. Process the ingredients together.

3. Add the vanilla and pulse together. If the dough is not sticking together, add 1-5 teaspoons of water (start with 1 and add more as needed). Continue to process until the dough starts to form a ball or at least sticks together when pinched.

4. Spread the dough out and sprinkle the raisins on top. Fold the dough together until the raisins are well incorporated into the mixture.

5. Roll the dough into 12-15 small balls. Place the bites into a large glass container. Enjoy as is, or transfer to the fridge or the freezer to allow it to set.

Variations: Omit the raisins for a cinnamon oatmeal bite. Swap the dates with raisins. Use hemp seeds in place of cashews.

node.text:
Exercise may help prevent age-related immune decline. Sedentary women in their seventies, for example, may have a 50 percent chance of getting an upper respiratory illness during the fall season every year, but their risk drops down to 20 percent when they walk just half an hour a day.⁠
⁠
As we go from inactive to active, our infection risk declines, but, if we overtrain as hardcore athletes often do, we may put excessive stress on our body and actually increase our risk of infection.⁠
⁠
Beta glucan, a special type of fiber found in baker’s, nutritional, and brewer’s yeasts, may prevent this immune decline in marathon runners. Indeed, a study found that we can better maintain our level of circulating white blood cells after exhaustive exercise by consuming beta glucan.⁠
⁠
Watch the video “Preserving Immune Function in Athletes with Nutritional Yeast” at https://bit.ly/3tPt9zI to learn more.⁠
⁠
⁠

node.text:
Stone Fruit Bowls from the How Not to Diet Cookbook, a delicious summer dessert recipe. 

A drupe, more commonly known as stone fruit, is so named because it contains a stone (or a pit) inside. Many popular stone fruits, such as cherries, plums, peaches, nectarines, mangoes, and dates are in season in late summer. 

INGREDIENTS:
3 tablespoons ground chia seeds
1 1/2 cups fresh or thawed frozen diced mango
1 teaspoon fresh lemon juice
2 pitted soft dates, soaked for 10 minutes in hot water and then drained
3 ripe apricots, pitted and quartered
3 ripe plums, pitted and cut into 1-inch pieces
2 ripe peaches or nectarines, pitted and cut into 1-inch pieces
2 cups pitted cherries

METHOD:
In a small bowl, combine the chia seeds and 1/4 cup water and mix well. Set aside for 10 minutes to thicken.

In a food processor or a blender, combine the mango, lemon juice, dates, and the chia mixture and process until smooth. Divide equally among four small glass dessert bowls. Cover and refrigerate until firm (about 4 hours).

Combine the apricots, plums, peaches, and cherries in a large bowl. Toss gently to combine.

To serve, spoon the fruit evenly over the chilled mango mixture. Serve immediately.

Serves 4
